content.key_points:
**West Nile virus transmission and prevention:**

- **Transmission**: West Nile virus causes inflammation of the brain
- **Vector**: It is transmitted to humans by the bite of a mosquito
- **Reservoir**: Birds serve as the reservoir of the West Nile virus
- **Vectors**: Mosquitoes serve as the vectors
- **Incubation period**: From 5 to 15 days
- **Early manifestations**: Fever, headache, and body malaise
- **Prevention**: Apply insect repellant on the skin like DEET (N-diethyl-metatoluamide)
- **Additional transmission routes**: WN virus can be transmitted through a bite of infected mosquito, blood transfusion, organ transplant, breast milk, and transplacental (mother-to-child)

**CONCEPT**: West Nile virus is transmitted by the bite of infected mosquito

questions.question_text: Which of the following instructions will help prevent infection with West Nile virus?
questions.rationale: **RATIONALE**\n\nThe West Nile virus is transmitted to humans by the bite of a mosquito (primarily Culex species) infected with the virus. Eliminating mosquito breeding places will reduce the risk of becoming infected.

extraction_metadata.notes: Left side content from PDF page 152 - complete concept with question, options, answer and rationale about West Nile virus prevention
extraction_metadata.reference: Handbook of infectious Diseases, Pennsylvania, Springhouse
